[[User:Crisco 1492|Crisco 1492]] ([[User talk:Crisco 1492|talk]]) 16:06, 3 December 2011 (UTC) ==Notes== *''Chinezenmoord'' really means "murder of Chinese". *"Because of unrest in the Chinese population": a quick note (half a sentence, no more) on the reason for that unrest would be helpful ("because of years of racial repression"; "after suffering through another government-inflicted typhoid epidemic"; "caused by a year-long shortage of oliebollen") *Count how many sentences and clauses start with "this" *"one of the most important events in 18th century [Dutch] colonialism"...hmm, yes, but ''markant'' means characteristic, even odd, more than important. The function of ''markant'' is to mark (there's the etymology) something as noteworthy. Maybe "[http://german.about.com/library/definitions/bldef_04_0630.htm prominent]" is a good translation; my Prisma dictionary has "striking, outstanding"--I would go with "striking". [[User:Crisco 1492|Crisco 1492]] ([[User talk:Crisco 1492|talk]]) 09:01, 29 December 2011 (UTC) ==My findings== * On your question above [http://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adriaan_Valckenier] which was "composed" by me long time ago. * In 1739 too much sugar and not enough coffee was sent to the Netherlands [http://books.google.nl/books?id=a2ymsrpA-iMC&pg=PA81&dq=Valckenier+Van+Imhoff+1740+Batavia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ljz8TrqBHYyj-gbp84WyAQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Valckenier%20Van%20Imhoff%201740%20Batavia&f=false] * A very good account in German [http://books.google.nl/books?id=RYQeAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA39&dq=Valckenier+Van+Imhoff+1740+Batavia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hkP8ToeYBoKk-gapoqG5AQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Valckenier%20Van%20Imhoff%201740%20Batavia&f=false] * Van Imhoff and the other two were arrested on 6 December 1740 [http://www.vocsite.nl/geschiedenis/personalia/vanimhoff.html][http://books.google.nl/books?id=ou4YAAAAYAAJ&q=Valckenier+Van+Imhoff+1740+Batavia&dq=Valckenier+Van+Imhoff+1740+Batavia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hkP8ToeYBoKk-gapoqG5AQ&redir_esc=y] * Take a look at the engraving here [http://www.rijksmuseum.nl/collectie/zoeken/asset.jsp?id=RP-P-OB-75.360&lang=nl] * Looks like an accurate account, but again be careful, each auther has his own view on the chronology.[http://books.google.nl/books?id=ro8SLhyAc9AC&pg=PA263&dq=Valckenier+Van+Imhoff+1740+Batavia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ljz8TrqBHYyj-gbp84WyAQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Valckenier%20Van%20Imhoff%201740%20Batavia&f=false] *The three gentlemen were sent to the Netherlands, each on a different ship [http://www.vocsite.nl/geschiedenis/personalia/valckenier.html]. [[User:Crisco 1492|Crisco 1492]] ([[User talk:Crisco 1492|talk]]) 04:58, 17 April 2012 (UTC) ==Increased exports/decreased prices?== "Because of the decline of worldwide sugar prices that began in the 1720s caused by an increase in exports to Europe, the sugar industry in the East Indies had suffered considerably." Why would increasing exports to Europe cause prices to decline? Higher demand usually creates higher prices. But is something missing here? Were exports to Europe now coming from the West Indies, instead of the East Indies? If so, that should be made clear because it leaves alot of questions now. [[User:Alanscottwalker|Alanscottwalker]] ([[User talk:Alanscottwalker|talk]]) 02:53, 4 September 2012 (UTC) *[[Supply and demand]], mostly. More exports = less of an asking price. — [[User:Crisco 1492|Crisco 1492]] ([[User talk:Crisco 1492|talk]]) 03:01, 4 September 2012 (UTC) *See also ''[http://books.google.co.id/books?id=a2ymsrpA-iMC&pg=PA80&lpg=PA80&dq=price+sugar+1740+chinese+Dutch&source=bl&ots=kr9iwuDXDl&sig=ACaIfr4lZnvzBS_ni2Pd-szUfuY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=p3BFUN-0MMXSrQfM14DACQ&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=price%20sugar%201740%20chinese%20Dutch&f=false The Life of Governor Joan Gideon Loten]'' and ''[http://books.google.co.id/books?id=ybAHcV9thhAC&pg=PA390&lpg=PA390&dq=increase+sugar+1740&source=bl&ots=VB74KnqZF2&sig=W781jqAr1_H-mVHX22cIo-OJSbs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=FXBFUNHrEpDjrAemzoD4Bw&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=increase%20sugar%201740&f=false Dutch Primacy in World Trade]'' — [[User:Crisco 1492|Crisco 1492]] ([[User talk:Crisco 1492|talk]]) 03:10, 4 September 2012 (UTC) **Supply and demand would initially suggest the prices would go up as the initial comment suggested, normally more exports = more demand = higher asking price. I couldn't see the first link you provide, but the second one suggests a further step - increase in demand in Europe caused an increase in the amount of sugar mills to supply enough for that demand, and then presumably the competition from all those extra mills could then push the price back down (or maybe even lower than before), especially with the time lag of transport at that time on global trade meaning it would be easy to overbuild and cause an oversupply. --[[Special:Contributions/81.149.74.231|81.149.74.231]] ([[User talk:81.149.74.231|talk]]) 10:40, 4 September 2012 (UTC) ***There's also increased competition from other countries/colonies, including the West Indies. This has been indicated in the article. — [[User:Crisco 1492|Crisco 1492]] ([[User talk:Crisco 1492|talk]]) 10:59, 4 September 2012 (UTC) ==Pogrom?== Who has called this event a pogrom? [[User:Viriditas|Viriditas]] ([[User talk:Viriditas|talk]]) 18:45, 4 September 2012 (UTC) :It looks like the primary contributor is citing the doctoral thesis of W. W. Dharmowijono who uses the word informally twice.[http://dare.uva.nl/document/147345] See pages 302-303: :
Waarschijnlijk komt dat omdat de regering in overeenstemming met de publieke mening de pogrom gerechtvaardigd vond, zodat het niet nodig gevonden werd daar iets tegen te doen...In het algemeen kan gezegd worden dat verschillende omstandigheden samen een toestand creëerden die leidden naar de pogrom in Batavia.
:From Google translate: :
Probably because the government in accordance with the public opinion the pogrom was justified, so it was not seen as something to do ... In general it can be said that different circumstances together created a situation that led to the pogrom in Batavia.
:So, it appears he's referring to the massacre informally as a pogrom, and doesn't mention it further for 325 pages. We generally do not cite a doctoral thesis as the sole authoritative source for a subject and use that as the basis of an encyclopedia article, especially when the term is used in passing.
